;供应链从中国转移的势头越来越大，这种转变反映了外国根据一家领先的欧洲贸易协会的最新调查结果，投资者对中国市场的信心正在减弱，而东盟市场的吸引力正在上升。

;

;欧盟商会最新的商业信心调查在中国的调查显示，11% 的受访成员已经将部分投资移出中国，计划今年在世界第二大经济体扩张的公司数量创历史新低。

;

;“随着去风险策略的出现，投资开始从中国转移，”商会周三发布的最新报告称，该报告基于 2 月至 5 月期间对 570 家公司的调查——46% 的回复率。

;

;此消息发布之际，李强总理正在访问欧盟，这是他担任总理后的首次出访，着眼于促进与欧盟主要大国的关系。

;

;中国总理访问德国以巩固“混乱”中的关系和变化”

;

;最新报告还表示，另有 20% 的人正在考虑将投资转移到其他地方或推迟做出任何此类决定，因为他们正在等待观察 2023 年中国商业环境的演变情况。

;< p>;“面对越来越大的风险和更加动荡的经营环境，欧洲公司仍在重新评估在他们的中国篮子里放多少鸡蛋，”报告说。

;

;东南亚国家联盟的成员国正在报告称，这两个市场将成为供应链搬迁的主要目的地，其次是欧洲市场，因为这两个市场占搬迁计划的 48%。

;

;同时，十分之一的欧洲公司在中国，他们表示已经或计划将其亚洲总部迁出大陆。

;

;新加坡 (43%) 和马来西亚 (17%) 是新总部的前两个选择, 报告称，在有意搬迁的人群中，香港占 9%。

;

;需要增强弹性、应对地缘政治风险并减轻国内政策（例如中国的自给自足计划）的影响是影响公司供应链决策的三大因素，它说。

;

;“这表明企业正在考虑将投资主要用于降低风险和建立弹性，而不是纯粹出于商业原因，”商会写道。

;

;对中国市场的信心进一步削弱，因为只有 55% 的受访公司认为中国是未来投资的前三大目的地——低于 2022 年的 68%，这也是创纪录的低。

;

;尽管中国在 12 月取消了限制性的零 Covid 控制，但根据商会的调查结果，将继续看到近三年政策的挥之不去的影响。

;

;统一的国内市场有助于解决中国经济增长问题？

;

;航空航天行业以及医疗器械行业最不愿意扩大在中国的投资。

;

;报告称：“零 Covid 已经结束，但必须谨慎应对即将出现的挑战，以恢复商业信心。”

;

;自 2016 年以来，商会接受调查的公司中首次有不到一半的计划今年将扩大在中国的投资，从 2022 年的 62% 下降到 46%。

;

;尽管企业并未完全放弃中国市场，但脱钩也在加剧，供应链战略继续演变为报告称，对冲监管不确定性和地缘政治紧张局势。

;

;四分之三的受访者审查了过去两年的供应链战略，近四分之一打算进一步或完全将在岸供应链引入中国.

;

;“欧洲企业在中国经营时面临的挑战越来越多，这促使许多企业将其在中国的业务本地化并孤立起来。越来越多的人正在创建两个独立的系统，一个用于中国，一个用于世界其他地区——包括供应链、数据和信息技术 (IT) 系统以及人员配备——这是一种昂贵且低效的解决方案。”

;

;报告表明，在过去两年中，27% 的受访公司发现其总部与中国业务脱钩，高于去年的 20%。

;

;“公司总部与中国业务之间的脱节中国业务有可能进一步损害对中国市场的信心，引发分歧的恶性循环，”报告称。

;

;北京今年加强了魅力攻势以吸引海外投资者，但外国商人继续重申长期以来，人们一直抱怨“承诺疲劳”。

;

;欧盟商会指出，“市场开放仅迈出了一小步”，因为两分之一的公司认为市场准入没有变化。

;

;模糊的规章制度、不可预测的立法环境和市场准入障碍导致数量“惊人”的欧洲公司表示他们已经错失商机。

;

;根据报告，创历史新高的 62% 的欧洲公司报告说失去了商业机会，比去年的 42% 大幅上升。

;

;“政府有机会证明亲商其领导层最近做出的承诺不仅仅是口头上的，”报告说。

;中国消费者在放松钱包方面仍持谨慎态度，许多人倾向于淘便宜货全球咨询公司贝恩公司和市场研究公司凯度消费者指数的联合研究显示，在经济前景黯淡的情况下。

;

;报告显示，中国内地快速消费品 (FMCG) 的平均售价在北京从其零 Covid 策略转变为与病毒共处之后，中国第一季度同比下降 0.8%。

;

;消费品总支出增长 1.9%，而销量小幅增长报告显示 2.7%，但没有透露绝对数字。

;

;“2020 年开始的价格通缩趋势一直持续到 2023 年第一季度，但各类别之间的差异更大，”Jason Yu，周二，凯度大中华区董事总经理在媒体吹风会上表示。

;

;中国在经过三年的严格疫情遏制后于 1 月重新开放经济，这增加了人们对国内消费快速复苏的希望。然而，内地消费者对就业前景和收入增长感到不安，他们控制了支出，导致从瓶装水生产商到面巾纸制造商的消费品制造商都在努力提高销售额。

;

;Bruno Lannes，a上海贝恩资本合伙人警告说，零售额增长需要时间才能回升。

;

;“快速消费品行业在 2 月份开始了增长轨迹，[但]全面复苏需要时间，我们认为第一个季度数字跟踪良好，”他说。

;

;他补充说，中国消费者似乎更愿意在餐饮和旅游等服务上花钱，而不是在消费品上花钱。

;

; “被低估”的中国消费类股即将迎来转机：摩根士丹利

;

;第一季度，家庭护理产品的增幅最高，支出同比增长 13%，平均售价上涨 3.2%，报告显示。

;

;“他们不一定会购买最便宜的商品，但他们会一丝不苟地寻找既能满足他们需求又能以相对较低的价格提供的产品，”Kantar 的 Yu 说。 “当品牌在大促销期间降价时，一些人会购买大量商品，例如日常必需品。”

;

;5 月份，中国的居民消费价格指数 (CPI) 同比仅上涨 0.2%数据提供商万得资讯在上海进行的一项分析师调查显示，低于 0.3% 的预测。

;

;中国央行行长易纲在实地考察时告诉企业高管本月早些时候，上海宣布 CPI 将在年底前升至 1%。

;

;贝恩资本上海的另一位合伙人 Derek Deng 表示，中国政府的刺激政策将恢复消费者信心。

;

; p>;

;“政府已经实施了刺激消费的刺激政策，预计还会有更多，”他说。 “快速消费品行业继续展现出韧性，消费者、品牌和零售商也在适应不断变化的环境。”

;香港约有 1,000 家食品店（从咖啡店到餐厅）同意参加庆祝活动行业负责人透露，通过提供折扣来庆祝 7 月 1 日的交接周年纪念日，并有望在正常的周末或公共假期享受 15% 至 20% 的业务增长。

;

;Simon Wong Ka-wo，总裁香港餐饮联业联会周二晚告诉邮报，食品和餐饮业希望通过加入该倡议获得一剂强心针。

;

;香港提供免费乘车服务和博物馆7 月 1 日回归纪念日的访问

;

;行政长官李家超周二上午宣布了一系列活动和免费赠品，以纪念 7 月 1 日香港回归中国统治 26 周年，包括 29% 的餐厅折扣，或“支付 71% 的价格”。图为“7/1”，指的是7月1日。

;

;“很多本地人在过去的几个公共假期都选择出国旅游，所以这往往是一个相当困难的时期为了我们。我们期待这些折扣能给我们带来提振，”Wong 说，他预测业务将增长 15% 到 20%。

;

;7 月 1 日是香港的公众假期。

;

;同时也是餐厅经理协会发言人的南区区议员 Jonathan Leung Chun 表示，这与其说是数字，不如说是振奋精神。

;

;“这是自限制以来的第一个 7 月 1 日他说：“疫情已经缓解，所以我们希望庆祝并尽自己的一份力量。”所有人都可以自由地以他们喜欢的方式展示 29% 的折扣。

;

;“它可以是一顿饭中的一杯饮料或一道特定的菜，”他说。

;

;一位与政府关系密切的消息人士表示，庆祝活动可能会促进消费。

;

;《华盛顿邮报》已联系行政长官办公室征求意见。

;

;随着香港人出行和中国大陆游客的到来，餐馆陷入困境待在家里

;

;中文大学亚太商学院名誉研究员、经济学家李少波表示，他认为餐厅提供的折扣不会产生可观的额外收入。< /p>;

;“在任何一家香港餐厅用餐都不便宜，”他说。 “许多人可能会选择去海外旅行和消费。”

;

;他指出周二发布的年度世界竞争力报告显示，香港在 2023 年的 64 个经济体中排名第七，比一年前下降了两个等级，主要是因为价格上涨。

;

;尽管如此，这位经济学家表示，这将是几年来第一次没有 Covid-19 大流行阴影的交接庆祝活动，预计会充满欢乐。< /p>;

;香港最后一个公众假期是 5 月 26 日佛诞。根据入境事务处的数据，5 月 24 日至 26 日期间，有 877,298 名居民离开香港，而包括本地人和游客在内的 835,116 人入境。

;法国正在派遣一艘专业船只协助营救在北方失踪的潜水器大西洋正在潜入泰坦尼克号的残骸。

;

;Atalante 研究船有一个潜水机器人，正前往该地区寻找正在前往泰坦尼克号残骸的潜水器，作为救援人员与时间赛跑，因为可呼吸的空气量下降。

;

;隶属于海洋研究所 Ifremer 的法国船只已经在执行任务，但定于周三晚上抵达法国政府所在地据广播公司 BFMTV 的报道，海洋部长埃尔韦·贝尔维尔说。

;

;接受过操作潜水机器人培训的专家，该机器人可以下沉到更深的深度，从法国南部的土伦出发，领导对他说。

;

;“与北约协调中心联络的安排仍在继续，我们正在与美国当局保持联系，”伯维尔说。他补充说，机器人的操作员将于周三早上抵达加拿大纽芬兰。

;

;Victor 6000 机器人通过长达 8 公里的绳索从研究船远程控制，Ifremer 将其描述为“水下作业的旗舰设备”，BFMTV 说。该机器人可以部署在最深 6,000 米（约 20,000 英尺）的深度。

;

;失踪的潜水器上的人员包括法国研究员和前海军军官保罗-亨利·纳吉奥莱特，他因其专业知识而被称为“泰坦尼克号先生”在沉船上。其他人是英国商人 Shahzada Dawood 和他的儿子 Suleman，以及 OceanGate Expeditions 的首席执行官兼创始人 Stockton Rush。

;

;他们的潜水器在周日被报告失踪。

;

;谁是在失踪的泰坦尼克号旅游潜水器上？

;

;这艘法国船只将加入不断扩大的国际舰船和飞机舰队，搜索该地区。

;

;美国海岸警卫队官员表示，搜索范围达 26,000 平方公里（10,000平方英里），但到目前为止还没有发现被称为泰坦的潜水器的迹象。尽管他们计划继续寻找，但时间已经不多了，因为船上只剩下不到两天的氧气。

;

;“这是一次非常复杂的搜索，统一的团队正在夜以继日地工作，”船长波士顿第一海岸警卫区的杰米·弗雷德里克 (Jamie Frederick) 在新闻发布会上说。

;

;弗雷德里克 (Frederick) 说，截至周二中午，船员的氧气还剩大约 40 小时。他补充说，有人推动将打捞设备运到现场，以防找到潜艇。

;

;美国军方的三架 C-17 也被用来从美国运送一家商业公司的潜水器和支持设备美国空军机动司令部的一位女发言人说，纽约布法罗到纽芬兰圣约翰斯协助搜索。

;

;当局报告说，这艘碳纤维船周日晚上逾期未到，于是开始在水域进行搜索在圣约翰以南约 700 公里（435 英里）处。

;

;据 OceanGate Expeditions 的顾问 David Concannon 说，这艘潜水器在周日早上 6 点左右出海时有 96 小时的氧气供应，该公司负责监督使命。这意味着氧气供应可能会在周四早上耗尽。

;

;CBS 新闻记者大卫波格去年乘坐泰坦号前往泰坦尼克号，他说这艘船使用两种通信系统：来回发送短信到水面舰艇，每 15 分钟发出一次安全信号，表明潜艇仍在工作。

;

;失踪的泰坦尼克号潜艇的老板曾称他的行业“非常安全”

;

;两者这些系统中的一部分在泰坦淹没后大约 1 小时 45 分钟停止。

;

;“只有两件事可能意味着。要么他们失去了所有动力，要么船体发生了船体破裂并立即内爆。 Pogue 周二告诉 CBC，这两种方法都毫无希望可言。

;

;这艘潜水器有七个备用系统可以返回水面，包括沙袋和可掉落的铅管以及一个充气气球。 Pogue 说，即使船上的每个人都失去知觉，一个系统也能正常工作。

;

;阿德莱德大学造船中心主任 Eric Fusil 说，还有其他可能导致通信中断的情况，包括电气火灾这可能会产生有毒烟雾并使船员失去知觉。

;

;Fusil 说，另一种可能性是 Titan 与泰坦尼克号的残骸纠缠在一起并被困在那里。

;

;“我会他说，我喜欢相信……土卫六遭受了电力损失，但他们仍然可以返回水面”并被飞机和水面舰艇发现。

;

;专家表示，救援人员面临着严峻的挑战。

;

;伦敦大学学院海洋工程教授阿利斯泰尔·格雷格 (Alistair Greig) 说，潜水器通常有一个落锤，这是“在紧急情况下它们可以释放的质量，使它们浮出水面” .

;

;“如果出现电源故障和/或通信故障，这可能会发生，然后潜水器会在水面上漂浮，等待被发现，”Greig 说。

;

;首次全 3D 扫描捕获沉船时，泰坦尼克号“有故事可讲”

;

;另一种情况是耐压船体泄漏，在这种情况下，预后不佳，他说。

;

;“如果它已经沉入海底并且不能靠自己的力量爬起来，选择就非常有限，”格雷格说。 “虽然潜水器可能仍然完好无损，但如果它超出了大陆架，那么很少有船只能够到达那么深，当然也没有潜水员。”

;

;这次探险是 OceanGate 的第三次年度航行编年史泰坦尼克号的恶化，它于 1912 年撞上冰山并沉没，大约 2,200 名乘客和船员中只有大约 700 人遇难。残骸于 1985 年被发现，并一直在慢慢地死于食金属细菌。

;

;OceanGate 的网站将 2023 年探险的“任务支持费”描述为每人 25 万美元。

;

; Pogue 回忆起自己在泰坦号上的旅行时说，这艘船掉头寻找泰坦尼克号。

;

;“水下没有 GPS，因此水面舰艇应该通过发送短信将潜艇引导到沉船处”，Pogue 在“CBS 周日早上”播出的一个片段中说道。

;

;“但是在这次潜水中，通讯不知何故中断了。潜艇从未找到沉船。”

;A White House official hailed the significance of Washington's partnership with New Delhi on Tuesday as Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi arrived in New York for his first state visit to the United States. His trip comes as President Joe Biden's administration looks to forge closer ties with India to counter China's rising political and economic clout in Asia and beyond.

;

;Calling India a “key and important partner, not just in the Indo-Pacific but globally”, US National Security Council spokesman John Kirby said the US-India relationship was “one of the most defining and important bilateral relationships in the world now”.

;

;The remarks came a day after Secretary of State Antony Blinken concluded high-level meetings in Beijing as the US tries to prevent rising tensions with China from spiralling into a wider conflict.

;

;Kirby responded with a terse “no” when asked if the invitation to Modi was also a message to Beijing. “This state visit is not about China. ;

;He also said that Washington was looking to “deepen”, “broaden” and “improve” defence cooperation with New Delhi.

;

;In New York, Modi will meet with Tesla CEO Elon Musk about plans to open a manufacturing base in India as US firms look to shift supply chains away from China. On Thursday in Washington, Modi will hold talks with Biden and address a joint session of Congress. The day will conclude with a state dinner at the White House.

;

;The two leaders are expected to announce several defence industrial cooperation agreements, including the joint manufacture of F414 jet engines and India's acquisition of 31 MQ 9B drones worth US$3 billion.

;

;“Such collaboration will also help India bridge the massive gap in military capabilities with China with strong support from the United States,” C Raja Mohan, a non-resident senior fellow at Carnegie India, wrote in a report published by the Asia Society, a New York-based think tank.

;

;Can India be 'Global South champion' amid US-China rivalry in the Pacific?

;

;He said both New Delhi and Washington have a “strong interest in stabilising the Asian balance of power and coping with the geopolitical churn triggered by China's rise and Beijing's assertiveness in Asia”.

;

;However, Ashley Tellis of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a Washington-based think tank, said that New Delhi's “underlying objective is to secure technological autonomy” and that it had “prioritised Washington's support for its defence industrial ambitions in tandem with similar partnerships forged with France, Israel, Russia and other friendly states”.

;

;However, Manjari Chatterjee Miller of the Council on Foreign Relations called India's reliance on Russian oil and weapons one of the major challenges to US-India relations. Washington “worries about India's commitment to the norms of the current global order and its perceived reluctance to rock the geopolitical boat”, she said in the Asia Society report.

;

;Kirby would not speak about Washington trying to wean New Delhi off Russian arms, although he said “we certainly hope” that India “will continue to purchase oil inside the cap”. In December, the Group of Seven countries – the US, the UK, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan – along with Australia, imposed a price cap on imports of Russian oil by non-Western countries that they say have been funding Moscow's war in Ukraine.

;

;Biden's narrative of Modi's state visit has been shadowed by some Democrats' concerns about the Indian leader's record on human rights and press freedom.

;

;“It's shameful that Modi has been given a platform at our nation's capital – his long history of human rights abuses, anti-democratic actions, targeting Muslims & religious minorities, and censoring journalists is unacceptable”, Representative Rashida Tlaib, a Democrat from Michigan, said on Twitter. ;

;Representative Pramila Jayapal, a Democrat from Washington state, and Senator Chris Van Hollen, a Democrat from Maryland, sent a letter with more than 70 other lawmakers asking Biden to “discuss the need to protect human rights and democratic values in India” as he meets with Modi.

;

;Asked about the rolling out of the red carpet for Modi – who was once denied a US visa after riots killed 1,000 people, mostly minority Muslims, under his leadership as the chief minister of Gujarat province in 2002 – Kirby said Biden would not hesitate to bring up difficult issues with his guest.

;

;India gets a 'free pass' on rights concerns as US-China rivalry deepens

;

;“President Biden has never shied away from raising concerns over human rights, and he's not going to start shying away from it this week,” he said.

;

;Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International on Tuesday screened a BBC documentary on the 2002 violence. The film was banned by the Indian government in June as a “propaganda piece, designed to push a particular discredited narrative”.

;

;Rights groups have raised concerns about the persecution of minorities in India as well as the treatment of critics and journalists under Modi's Hindu-nationalist government.

;

;US nears deal to make jet engines in India as allies close ranks against China

;

;A report this year by Freedom House, a US government-funded non-profit organisation, described India as “partly free” for the third year in a row, adding that “democratic rights in India remain under pressure, particularly for marginalised groups”.

;

;When asked if Biden would host a joint news conference with Modi, who has not held a single press conference since taking office in 2014, Kirby was non-committal.

;“I can tell you that we're still working our way through some of the aspects of the agenda, and that's one of them,” he said.

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 05:20:02 +0800 Blood-red Mormon crickets invade US town, as residents fight backhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3224809/blood-red-mormon-crickets-invade-us-town-residents-fight-back?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.21 03:38;
;;

;Dana Dolan was driving through her small Nevada hometown when she thought she had come upon a gory crash. The ground surrounding Elko's stretch of Interstate 80 looked as if it had been covered in blood. As the red colour shifted and moved, she realised instead it was an infiltration of crickets, some bigger than her thumb.

;

;“It's almost like a biblical plague,” Dolan said, laughing at the absurdity of the situation that is playing out in Elko, where she has lived for six years.

;

;Tens of thousands of Mormon cricket eggs buried about an inch deep in the soil began to hatch in late May and early June. For weeks, the red critters have been invading swathes of northern Nevada and causing chaos, said the state's long-time entomologist Jeff Knight.

;

;The invasion of the cannibalistic crickets has hit especially hard in Elko, a small town of about 20,000 near Idaho and Utah known for its gold mining.

;

;The big red bugs leave behind a stench so horrible, akin to burning flesh, that it forces residents to plug their noses while driving. The critters stick to tyres and the bottoms of shoes, and their carcasses are everywhere, even in gyms. When they move, it sounds like rain, Dolan says.

;

;Residents and workers have tried to use brooms, leaf blowers, pressure washers and snow ploughs to get rid of the crickets, only for them to return. State officials have erected signs throughout Elko County warning drivers of slick highways, a popular hang-out spot for insects that will not think twice about eating their dead friends.

;

;The red creatures blanket highways and scuttle over barriers, seeking food. They crackle and pop under the wheels of trucks, creating something like an oil slick, said Jeremiah Moore of Spring Creek, whose vehicle slid off the road after a highway encounter with the Mormon crickets.

;

;“I … was coming home and as I came around the corner, I came around a little too fast and I about ended up in the ditch full of water,” Moore said. “It was pretty intense.”

;

;Why locusts swarm: scientists identify scent that could be used as weapon

;

;One hospital even hired four temporary, part-time employees whose main duty was to clear the campus of the crickets long enough for patients to enter the building. The group called itself the Cricket Patrol.

;

;“We're just trying to keep them moving on their way,” said Steve Burrows, a spokesman for Northeastern Nevada Regional Hospital.

;

;When the Cricket Patrol was not on duty, Burrows said, other hospital employees stepped in.

;

;There was the medical worker in the cardiology unit who, still in his black scrubs, went outside the hospital's ambulance bay between seeing patients to swat crickets away with a broom, Burrows said. And the IT specialists who helped with clean-up efforts.

;

;Outbreaks of Mormon crickets, which are native to the Great Basin and Intermountain West, have been recorded throughout history across the west – from Nevada and Montana to Idaho, Utah and Oregon. There are records of infestations dating to the 1930s, according to entomologist Knight.

;

;Legend has it the insects got their name when they started devastating crops planted by Mormon settlers who had moved into the Salt Lake valley in Utah, Knight said.

;

;“The settlers prayed for relief,” Knight said. “That came in the form of seagulls. Seagulls ate the crickets … That's also why they're the state bird of Utah.”

;

;In Oregon, state lawmakers in recent years have allocated millions of dollars to assess the problem and set up a Mormon cricket and grasshopper “suppression” programme.

;

;Salted crickets, chocolate beetles: insect snack machine's a hit in Japan

;

;The Mormon cricket is not a true cricket but a shield-backed katydid. They are flightless but travel together in “bands” that can range in size from 5 acres (2 hectares) acres to hundreds of acres, Knight said.

;

;Yet the invasion in Elko this year is not unprecedented for its size but for its timing.

;

;The crickets hatched far later than their usual springtime birth, delayed by an especially wet spring and snow-packed winter in northern Nevada, Knight said.

;

;Each spring – or summer, in this case – the crickets born that year will mate and lay a new generation of eggs in the soil. Those eggs are meant to hatch the following spring, but some will lay dormant in the soil for up to 11 years, Knight said. Eggs can accumulate in the dirt for years until a drought comes along, triggering the sleepy eggs to hatch all at once. And then the cycle repeats.

;

;In his nearly 40 years working for the Nevada Department of Agriculture – 32 of those as the state entomologist – Knight said he can recall four invasions. The infestation in the early 2000s “was most impressive in my mind, looking at the overall scope”, he said.

;

;Knight remembers one time driving from Reno to Utah on Interstate 80 and being surrounded by a swarm of red nearly the entire drive.

;

;“Then we can go almost 10, 15 years without hardly seeing any,” Knight said of the crickets. “From about 2008, we hardly had any crickets, until about 2019. ”

;

;Elko's new red residents will not be moving out until at least mid-August, much to everyone's despair. But where do the crickets go when they leave?

;

;They die, Knight said. The male crickets after they mate. The female crickets after laying their eggs.

;

;Li did not comment on Russia, and reporters were not granted questions at what was billed as a news event, after Berlin agreed to a request from the visitors from Beijing.

;

;In an interview last week with the South China Morning Post in Brussels, Fu Cong, the Chinese ambassador to the European Union, said that Beijing's position on the war was “very clear” and that “we do believe that the territorial integrity and sovereignty of all countries need to be respected”.

;

;Asked whether China would back a restoration of Ukraine's 1991 borders, which includes Crimea – illegally annexed by Russia since 2014 – Fu replied: “I don't see why not.”

;

;Li Qiang tells German firms don't mistake interdependence for insecurity

;

;“There are historical issues that need to be resolved by the two sides. And that's what we stand for, we do believe on issues such as Crimea, the two sides need to resolve them through peaceful negotiations,” he added.

;

;Li's visit to Berlin marked his first overseas trip since being elevated to premier in March, and he was given the red-carpet treatment – complete with military pageantry – upon arriving with his delegation of ministers for talks on Tuesday.

;

;For observers, it was difficult not to compare the scene to events in Brussels, where the European Union was pitching a new strategy to tackle what it sees as the confluence of economic and national security risks.

;

;The European Commission has recommended screening European hi-tech investments going into third countries, including China.

;

;By contrast in Berlin, both sides spoke of the need for deeper cooperation and dialogue. Chinese apparatchiks and German industry bosses posed for the cameras as they signed deals on climate dialogue, engineering, labour and investment.

;

;As EU competition chief Margrethe Vestager in Brussels was calling China a “systemic rival” that would be in the cross hairs of its economic security strategy, Li urged his German hosts to pursue closer ties, rather than divisions.

;

;“But if it's about using de-risking … to carry out decoupling or carry out discriminatory measures against certain countries … then it goes against market rules and principles of a level playing field,” said Li, until recently the Communist Party chief of Shanghai.

;

;“China is willing to work with Germany to push China-Germany relations to a new level, better serve the development of the two countries, and inject more positive energy and stability into the world,” he said, according to an account published by state media CCTV.

;

;Scholz, for his part, assured Li that Germany had “no interest in an economic decoupling from China,” and instead would pursue a level playing field for German companies in the country.

;

;“Direct dialogue, face-to-face talks, a real exchange – all this is even more important than usual in these extraordinary times full of global challenges and crises,” the chancellor said.

;

;The meeting came a week after Germany released its first-ever national security strategy which accused China of “trying in various ways to reshape the existing rules-based international order”. In around a fortnight, it will unveil its long-delayed China strategy, which is expected to promote a more hard-headed approach to the world's second largest economy.

;

;Germany eyes 'systemic rival' China in first-ever national security strategy

;

;Moritz Rudolf, an analyst at Yale University's Paul Tsai China Centre, said the talks were “by far the most political ever” between the two governments.

;

;“Usually, expanding economic and cultural cooperation dominated. This time, both sides focused on their respective global responsibilities and how to coordinate here – this is new,” Rudolf said.

;

;The 10 agreements signed were modest compared to previous occasions, he said, and also included debt relief for developing countries and public health, so they “made sense”.

;

;“The question is whether the Chinese side is willing and able to deliver on Li's promises. They have a lot to lose in the bilateral relations with Germany, and they appear to acknowledge this,” Rudolf added.

;

;Yet for some analysts, the choreography represented a continuation of the close bilateral ties of the Angela Merkel era.

;

;“Scholz steered clear of the controversial themes. There was no mention of Taiwan, Xinjiang or Hong Kong. And he did not mention de-risking, although he did dismiss the idea of decoupling. It was far softer than the remarks he made in Beijing back in November,” said Noah Barkin, an analyst of Sino-German relations at the Rhodium Group research house.

;

;“It looked very much like a press conference Angela Merkel might have held years ago, when relations between Berlin and Beijing were in a better place. The only difference is that she always insisted that journalists be allowed to ask questions. Scholz bowed to Chinese demands on this.”

;;2023.06.21 03:00;
;;

;The nuclear non-proliferation regime permits access to nuclear technology for peaceful purposes, forbids non-nuclear-weapon states from making weapons using this technology and urges states with nuclear weapons to pursue disarmament in good faith.

;

;The safety and security of nuclear technology is also part of the regime's mandate. However, it has been influenced by major global geopolitical developments throughout its existence – the Ukraine war being a case in point.

;

;This conflict has recalibrated the importance of nuclear weapons in the global political system, giving rise to the debate about whether Russia would have taken the steps it did had Ukraine been in possession of nuclear weapons. The lesson here is that nuclear weapons are essential for establishing a deterrent and ensuring the survival of a state, particularly in the face of a nuclear-armed or conventionally strong rival.

;

;Last year, former Japanese prime minister Shinzo Abe said Japan should consider hosting US nuclear weapons, a suggestion turned down by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida. Poland revealed it had approached the US about sharing nuclear weapons, although a White House official said they were unaware of the issue being raised. Iran said it had the capacity to develop nuclear weapons, but does not intend to do so.

;

;In January this year, South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol said the country would consider building nuclear weapons or asking the US to deploy them on its territory if the North Korean nuclear threat grew. However, in April, the country agreed with the US that Washington would periodically send US nuclear-armed submarines to South Korea and involve Seoul in its nuclear planning.

;

;More countries acquiring nuclear weapons would undermine the effectiveness of the nuclear non-proliferation regime.

;

;For years, the New START treaty between Russia and the US accounted for 90 per cent of the world's nuclear warheads as the only operational arms control agreement, but it is now in limbo because of emerging great power politics.

;

;In response to US sanctions on Russia that hampered inspections of US nuclear facilities, Russian President Vladimir Putin announced earlier this year the suspension of his country's participation in the New START treaty. The actions of both sides are creating implications for arms control arrangements, and the failure to renew or replace this treaty could lead to a dangerous global arms race.

;

;The 2022 nuclear non-proliferation treaty review conference could not reach a consensus, mainly because of Russia's opposition to the inclusion of certain paragraphs in the draft document.

;

;Other matters of significance have been put on the back burner, such as the proliferation potential of nuclear-powered submarines provided to non-nuclear weapon states, Iran's uranium enrichment programme, North Korea's nuclear weapons programme and more. Although discussions and consensus on these matters were hardly prevalent earlier, the conflict in eastern Europe has made such initiatives even more difficult.

;

;If disagreements continue to prevail at these forums and the major actors fail to regulate such matters by establishing a consensus, it will make the non-proliferation regime unproductive.

;

;The chances of nuclear catastrophe are also high. Russia has issued warnings about the possibility of using nuclear weapons to deter intervention by Nato member countries. US tactical nuclear weapons are stationed in some Nato countries that are actively supporting Ukraine in the current conflict. Russia's decision to deploy its tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus could be seen as a response to what the US has been doing in Europe for decades, but these escalating tensions have adverse implications for all of humanity.

;

;While this is far from the first time that the threat of using nuclear weapons has emerged during a crisis or a state has deployed them in another state, the trust deficit among actors is at a different level compared to previous crises. It is continuously increasing, particularly after the virtual freezing of the New START treaty, one of the major confidence-building measures between nuclear players with a stake in the conflict.

;

;The safety and security of the Chernobyl and Zaporizhzhia nuclear plants in the conflict zone is another important issue. Russia and Ukraine have accused each other of deliberately endangering nuclear power plants. There has been regular fighting near the Zaporizhzhia plant, and in May, Russian authorities evacuated 18 settlements in the region.

;

;The International Atomic Energy Agency has been allowed access to the Zaporizhzhya plant, which is under Russian control, and raised serious concerns. Moscow has said that the radiation levels around the Chernobyl and Zaporizhzhia plants are normal, but the proximity of active conflict zones to nuclear power plants could pose grave risks.

;

;Russia and other nuclear states must be accountable for treaty violations

;

;The war in Ukraine is creating challenges for the nuclear non-proliferation regime by undermining existing non-proliferation arrangements, hindering consensus-building at non-proliferation forums and providing a stimulus for more countries to pursue nuclear weapon development. Hence, all parties to the conflict must adhere to agreed arms control arrangements.

;

;Urgent steps must be taken to prevent the further erosion of the global nuclear order besides restoring respect for international law and mutually agreed norms. Russia, Ukraine and the IAEA must design joint mechanisms to ensure the safety and security of nuclear power plants.

;

;Matters of global concern can be regulated by developing consensus and filling gaps in the nuclear order emerging in the wake of the Ukraine crisis to strengthen the nuclear non-proliferation regime and global security architecture.
